Description: Body sherd of large Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lid with part of flange; white slip; underside, with most of flange remaining, slipped; exterior: painted decoration consisting of procession of goats grazing to right (part of head and forelegs of one goat remaining); rising triangle and part of rising roundel as filling ornament; at rim, broad band; black dots on edge of lid; underside reserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Lemos, the sherd belongs to an Animal Chalice Style lid. However, goats are very rarely depicted on Animal Chalice Style vessels and the decoration on this sherd is consistent with the earlier Wild Goat Style. Lemos does not explain why she chooses to place in the later style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 271, no. 688, pl. 91)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2164) (phase 2)
